title.narrative: Promoting Eco-sanitation and Water Services in People?s Settlements in Kibera and Mukuru ? Nairobi Kenya ? Phase II

description.narrative: With a population approaching 3 million Nairobi is rapidly urbanizing and the peoples? settlements increasingly characterized by exclusion overcrowding and insalubrious conditions. Kibera and Mukuru as all of Nairobi?s informal and unplanned settlements ha ve limited access to sanitation facilities and water primarily due to lack of vehicular access and difficulty in establishing formalized water pipes or sewers. Most residents do not have access to adequate sanitation thus relying on filled-up latrines or o pen spaces and further increasing the thriving occurrence of water borne diseases.The overall objective of the proposed project is to increase the use of eco-friendly sanitation technologies and their by-products for improved health and livelihoods in the informal settlements of Kibera and Mukuru by means of improved management of human waste increased access to sanitation services and safe water and improved community health. The project continues to build on the ecological sanitation facilities constructe d in Phase I (bio-center and UDDTs) thus supporting existing structures but adding a new concept of closing the sanitation circle by focusing on end-use and marketing of the final products.The objective will be achieved through:a) Research development and marketing of by-products i.e. bio-gas from the bio-center and urine and compost from the composting latrinesb) Construction of one bio-center with water kioskc) Developing the capacity of community-based resource persons and artisans in the design planning and sustenance of ecological sanitation servicesd) Implementing a sanitation marketing process which embraces interactive hygiene promotion tools and methodse) Business development services share-holding in water and sanitation and participation in commun ity-managed water and sanitation financing facilityThe project will directly benefit 1500 users from the new and the already existing bio-centre as well as the pupils and teachers using composting latrines primarily through access to improved sanitation fa cilities, increase in artisan skills for 100 people increased hygiene promotion through 60 trained ToTs, and income generation from the sale of by-products and wages paid to the artisans. Equal access will be available to women men children and the disable d with efforts made to enhance gender equality and reduce inequalities among beneficiaries.
